newsitem.title: JAPAN: Sumitomo copper scandal trial to open on Feb 17.
newsitem.headline: Sumitomo copper scandal trial to open on Feb 17.

text.p: The trial of former Sumitomo copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka, blamed for the world's biggest financial scandal, will open next month, one of his lawyers said on Monday.
Hamanaka faces forgery and fraud charges in connection with an estimated $2.6 billion in losses allegedly run up over a 10-year period from unauthorised trades.
Toru Yoshiki, one of three lawyers representing Hamanaka, said they and Japanese prosecutors agreed last week to hold the first hearing on February 17 at Tokyo District Court.
Hamanaka, 49, was arrested last October on suspicion of forging the signature of one of his superiors at Sumitomo Corp on documents giving him authority to enter into certain copper transactions.
Sumitomo has blamed Hamanaka for what has been called the world's biggest financial trading loss.
Hamanaka's lawyers said late last year that he plans to plead guilty to charges that he forged documents relating to the company's huge losses on world copper markets.

While acknowledging guilt on the forgery counts, Hamanaka will deny that he manipulated world copper markets, concocted fictitious trades or received any personal benefit from his transactions, the lawyers said.
Before he was fired by Sumitomo last June, Hamanaka was considered the most influential and controversial player in the world copper market.
